creditline: The Robert J. Ulrich Works of Art Purchase Fund
inscription:
Inscription and Sticker

on leather wrap below back of bear's head, in black: [1/2505]
markings: on back on leather wrap, on sticker: [$(?)/ I-28]
medium: Burly hardwood (probably maple), abalone, steel, leather
text: Every Tlingit man owned and carried a fighting dagger, which was always by his side. The Tlingit referred to this type of dagger as quoth-lar, meaning to strike with the fist, and they used weapons like this against Native and non-Native enemies. The steel was probably salvaged from ship parts found on the shores of Alaska. The blade was Native-forged and is slightly concave for strength and ease of sharpening. The bear, a central theme in Tlingit art, is considered a relative to humans. It has spiritual power because of this, and is highly respected in Tlingit traditions. The pommel of this dagger is unusual for the exceptionally fine and highly detailed carving of the bear's open mouth and teeth.
title: Fighting dagger
